Award.AbstractNarration:
This award will provide funding for Integers 2013: The Erdos Centennial Conference, which will be held at the University of West Georgia,in Carrollton, Georgia, October 24-27, 2013. The Integers conferences, held bi-annually since 2003, serve to bring together mathematicians and students interested in combinatorics and number theory. The 2013 Integers conference will focus on the area broadlydefined as combinatorial number theory, a field in which Paul Erdos was vastly influential, and will pay tribute to his legacy. The conference will include talks on such topics as additive number theory, multiplicative number theory, combinatorial games, Ramsey theory, elementary number theory, and sequences.

The conference will feature several plenary speakers and about fifty additional speakers. In addition to the plenary speakers, a major portion of the funding will support a good number of graduate students, younger faculty, and female mathematicians. The conference will include at least ten student research talks. It will promote interaction among research mathematicians at all career stages from the talented undergraduate to the internationally distinguished researcher. The proceedings of the conference will be published as a special volume of the journal Integers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Integers 2013: The Erdos Centennial Conference was held October 24-27, 2013, at the University of West Georgia, in Carrollton, Georgia,  The conference focused on the mathematical areas of number theory and combinatorics, and was held in commemoration of the one hundredth anniversay of the birth of Paul Erdos. Erdos, one of the most celebrated mathematicians of the twentieth century, is often credited with being the founder of  the area of mathematics known as combinatorical number theory.

The conference featured several distinguished speakers, and included five one-hour plenary talks. The plenary speakers were Miklos Simonivits, Janos Pach, Alina Cojocaru, Andras Sarkozy, and Cameron Stewart. There were a total of fifty-eight talks given, representing recent research advances in such areas as additive number theory, multiplicative number theory, combinatorial game theory, Ramsey theory, algebraic number theory, probabilistic number theory, combinatorics and graph theory, and the theory of partitions.  

Ten of the speakers were students, including one undergraduate student. All of the stidemt talks were very well-received.  There were also several talks by early-career mathematicians. 

To help disseminate the research advances resulting from this meeting, all speakers were invited to submit expanded versions of their talks to the journal Integers, which plans to publish a special volume devoted to the Proceedings of this conference.  Seventeen articles were submitted for this volume; It is anticipated that it will be published in early 2015.
